title: 106_hr2261
content: The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999" is cited as the short title. It includes a new section, 25B, which provides a credit for health insurance costs for previously uninsured individuals and those with COBRA coverage. The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999" includes a new section, 25B, which allows a tax credit for health insurance costs paid by individuals for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The credit is equal to 60% of the amount paid during the taxable year, with a monthly limitation for eligible months. The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999" introduces section 25B, providing a tax credit for health insurance costs paid by individuals. The credit equals 60% of the amount paid during the taxable year, with a monthly limitation based on coverage type. The term 'eligible month' refers to a month starting at least 1 year after the individual was eligible for or participated in a group health plan providing qualified health insurance. The term 'eligible month' refers to a month starting at least 1 year after the individual was eligible for or participated in a group health plan providing qualified health insurance. In the case of a joint return, a month is eligible only if both spouses qualify separately. Amounts paid for coverage of an individual in a medical care program are not considered under subsection (a) if the individual is already covered at the start of the month. In subsection (a), an individual is considered covered under specific medical care programs listed in various sections of the Social Security Act, United States Code, and the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. There is a special rule for married individuals regarding eligibility. Special rule for married individuals: If an individual is married but does not file a joint return and does not live apart from their spouse during the taxable year, the limitation based on adjusted gross income applies to them. The limitation based on adjusted gross income applies to individuals, reducing the aggregate credit amount allowed under this section based on a specified ratio. The limitation on the credit amount is based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year, exceeding the applicable dollar amount, in relation to $10,000. The applicable dollar amount for the tax credit is $60,000 for coverage of more than one individual and $30,000 for coverage of a single individual. Amounts not multiples of $10 are rounded down. Qualified health insurance coverage under this section includes coverage for more than one individual, with a $30,000 limit for cases not described in subparagraph (A) or for married individuals filing separately. Marital status is determined under section 7703. The term 'qualified health insurance' refers to insurance that constitutes medical care, excluding coverage provided through group health plans or certain other contracts. The term 'qualified health insurance' excludes coverage through group health plans or certain other contracts. COBRA coverage under a group health plan is considered qualified health insurance, and the term 'eligible month' includes months of such coverage. The term 'qualified health insurance' includes coverage under COBRA and is treated as qualified health insurance. Special rules apply, such as coordination with other deductions and denial of credit to dependents. "Inflation adjustment for taxable year beginning after 2000 increases dollar amounts in subsection (c)(3) based on cost-of-living adjustment under section 1(f)(3)." The dollar amount for taxable year beginning after 2000 is adjusted based on the cost-of-living adjustment under section 1(f)(3), rounding to the nearest multiple of $100 if necessary. The dollar amount for taxable year beginning after 2000 is adjusted based on the cost-of-living adjustment under section 1(f)(3), rounding to the next lowest multiple of $100. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. SEC. 3. DEDUCTION FOR QUALIFIED HEALTH INSURANCE COSTS OF EMPLOYEES AND SELF-EMPLOYED INDIVIDUALS. This section introduces a new deduction for qualified health insurance costs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 222 allows for a deduction for the costs of qualified health insurance paid during the taxable year for the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. The applicable percentage is determined according to a specified table. The applicable percentage for qualified health insurance costs is determined according to a specified table, starting at 60% in 2000 and increasing to 100% in 2004 and thereafter. A special rule applies to employees under section 401(c)(1). The special rule applies to individuals who are employees under section 401(c)(1) and do not receive qualified health insurance through an employer's group health plan. The rule allows for a substitution of '100' for '90' in certain cases. Additionally, subsidized coverage under a group health plan of an employer excludes the taxpayer from the benefits of subsection (a). Additionally, subsidized coverage under a group health plan of an employer excludes the taxpayer from the benefits of subsection (a). The term 'qualified health insurance' is defined without regard to paragraph (2) of section 25B(d). The special rule applies to individuals who are employees under section 401(c)(1) and do not receive qualified health insurance through an employer's group health plan. This rule limits the amount taken into account under subsection (a) and excludes individuals from certain benefits. The special rule limits the amount taken into account under subsection (a) for taxpayers with earned income exceeding the amount without this rule. Amounts paid for insurance under subsection (a) are not considered for certain deductions. The special rule limits the amount taken into account for taxpayers with earned income exceeding a certain threshold. Amounts paid for insurance under this rule are not considered for certain deductions. The amendment to section 162(l) of the Code defines eligible long-term care premiums for qualified insurance contracts covering the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. Subsection (a) of section 62 is also amended to include this provision. The amendment strikes subparagraph (C) and adds a new item for the deduction of qualified health insurance costs. The table of sections is also updated accordingly. The amendments made by this section relate to the costs of qualified health insurance and have an effective date for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999.
